The service is set to allow up to 1000 [[Megabyte|MB]] of storage space. When Gmail was announced, this was vastly more than that of most other free [[webmail]] providers—for example, [[Microsoft]]'s [[Hotmail]] only offered 2 MB, and [[Yahoo!]]'s Mail service offered 4 MB. In response to Gmail, these limits have been upgraded, to 250 MB. Other webmail providers have followed suit, some of them now offering larger storage than Gmail. On [[November 13]], [[2004]] Google anounced that Gmail will be [[Post Office Protocol|POP3]] compatible and have e-mail forwarding for no extra charge. This means that people will be able to read their mail through a POP3 compatible e-mail client like [[Outlook Express]]. Most other online email services charge for a POP3 connectivity and message forwarding.
As of [[August 25]], [[2004]], the service was being tested internally. It is not known when the service will be made available to the public. However, the service is available to [[Blogger]] users and by invitation from current [[Gmail]] users. However, the invites system has led to Gmail invites being exchanged for cash and goods through websites like [http://www.gmailswap.com/ Gmail swap], making Google change its policy on invites by disallowing cash exchanges.
